source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: Out-of-pile experiments have been performed to investigate the escalation in temperature of Zircaloy-clad fuel rods during heatup in steam due to the exothermal Zircaloy steam reaction.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The initial heating rates were varied from 0.3 to 2.5 K/s.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The maximum measured surface temperature was about 2200°C.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: Damage to the fuel rods increased with increasing heatup rate.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxidation of zirconium in steam is an exothermal reaction, which may be written as Zr + 2H₂O → ZrO₂ + 2H₂ + 140 Kcal/mole

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: In the energy balance 255 Kcal/mole are gained by the uptake of oxygen and 115 Kcal/mole are lost by the dissociation of two moles water.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: This energy is sufficient to heat the fuel rod (Zircaloy and uranium dioxide [UO₂]) to about 3700°C including melting of both materials and neglecting any heat loss.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The zirconium oxide layer formed acts as a barrier to further oxidation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxide layer thickness thus has a parabolic time dependency. This may be expressed by W² = Kt or dW/dt = K/2 * 1/W

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: K = A exp(-B/RT)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The reaction rate thus increases exponentially with temperature and decreases with the reciprocal of the oxide layer thickness.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk1
evidence_span: The fuel rod simulators had lengths of 25 cm (ESSI-1 to ESSI-3) and 37 cm (ESSI-4 to ESSI-11).

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: In all tests a temperature escalation due to Zircaloy steam reaction was observed.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The maximum measured surface temperature was only about 2200°C.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The temperature at which the escalation begins increases with decreasing initial heatup rate.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: For fast initial heatup runoff of molten Zircaloy is a limiting process for the escalation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: There are indications that hydrogen blanketing may also have a limiting influence on the escalation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: For slow heatup the formation of a protective oxide layer is a mechanism that reduces the reaction energy.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: In these tests, with 120° steam entering at the lower end, the escalation started in the upper region and moved towards the lower end.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The damage to the fuel rods increases with the heatup rate.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: For slow heatup rates nearly no interaction between the oxidized cladding and the UO2 was observed.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: For fast heatup rates the entire annular pellet was dissolved by the molten Zircaloy.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparative study of the oxidation behavior of Zircaloy-4 versus austenitic stainless steel No. 1.4970 was performed in high-temperature steam.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: Nuclear reactor-type tube sections of both materials were exposed on both sides to superheated steam at temperatures ranging from 600 to 1300°C for up to 6 h.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: Nuclear reactor-type tube sections of both materials were exposed on both sides to superheated steam at temperatures ranging from 600 to 1300°C for up to 6 h.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The specimens were evaluated by gravimetry, metallography, and other methods.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The results are presented in terms of weight gain, corresponding metal consumption, and wall penetration as functions of time and temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The results are presented in terms of weight gain, corresponding metal consumption, and wall penetration as functions of time and temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The results are presented in terms of weight gain, corresponding metal consumption, and wall penetration as functions of time and temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: The two materials behaved similarly in that the faster oxidation of the thicker Zircaloy-4 cladding consumed the total wall thickness in a time equivalent to the slower oxidation of the thinner stainless steel cladding.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_052_chunk5
evidence_span: Besides oxide scale formation, oxygen diffusion into the bulk of the metal formed various oxygen-containing phases, which together influence the mechanical cladding properties.
